text: Thank you. It's been a mixed year due to COVID-19.  Can everybody hear me? We've noticed, Sue. Yes, and Zoom meetings, while good under the circumstances, have not been ideal. The Cambridge Community Board looks forward to returning to regular meetings as restrictions are eased. In April this year, the Community Board was able to hold ANZAC services at the Town Hall, unlike last year. The two services were well attended, particularly the dawn service, although it was very cold and as there were a small number of people present,  that required some assistance due to the cold, we may need to give some thought as to how we prepare for next year's service. The services are organised by a joint committee of the Community Board and the Cambridge RSA. The RSA members are excellent at ensuring that correct military protocols are followed. We are also grateful to the Cambridge Brass Band for their attendance and musicianship.  Sadly this year it was the Armistice services that had to be cancelled, though wreaths were laid at the Cenotaph, the Memorial Park gates and the RSA section of the Hatapu Cemetery. On November 4th, wreaths were also laid on behalf of the RSA and the Cambridge Community Port and  board and its Lekinwa committee at the Lekinwa sculpture to mark the anniversary of the liberation of our sister city Lekinwa in France by the New Zealand Regiment in 1918. Messages were exchanged with Lekinwa on this occasion and also on Anzac Day. In December, our sister city in Japan, Pohoro, sent Christmas gifts to the members of our community board  including face masks, much appreciated, and photographs. Arrangements have been made to reciprocate these gifts this Christmas. This year, the New Zealand Sister Cities Conference was held at Te Papa in Wellington and attended by Graeme Webber, Alana Makai and myself. There was some good discussion on the value of these international links that were largely positive. The Sister Cities organisation has undergone a name change. It is now Global Cities.  On the local scene, the community board has been busy. This year, we have established pop-up community gardens. This is a project led by board member Elise Badger, and she has received good help from council staff as to locations of preparation. Currently, there are three neighborhood pop-up vegetable gardens. Two are on reserves in Leamington, and the newest is on a street verge in Cambridge. Each garden has local guardians keeping a watch on them  And these gardens are proving to be popular with residents who are able to source vegetables, herbs, and fruit from these gardens. There will be more as we find suitable sites. The board is grateful to the council reserves team for their assistance in this project.  Jo Colley Davies is our representative on the Cambridge Committee of Social Services, which is a particularly busy committee in this community. And she's been able to keep the board up to date with the work being done in the community for those needing welfare and other assistance. Currently, that particular committee is running its annual Christmas chair program, providing food, children's Christmas gifts, and other necessities for those facing hardship. Our little library,  The Empire Street phone box continues to be very popular. This year it got a new paint job, new shelving, and a mural to cover the back view of a shelf. We have a local resident who's willing to pay for another secondhand phone box. They're actually quite expensive, but they have offered. And we would like a suitable site in Leamington, please. Another of our connections with the community is our rural tour.  Over two Saturdays in May, our board members, Cambridge councillors, and two regional councillors undertook our rural tour. We met with communities at Whitehall, Temiro, Fencourt, Horohoro, Mangatatari, and Mauna Whale. Attendances by locals at these halls varied, but discussions were interesting. Horohoro Hall was undergoing renovations, and a month or so later, we were invited to their re-opening.  Temera Hall had had an upgrade last year in time for the anniversary of their neighbouring Temera Schools reunion. And it was great to see the renovations. Finkholt Hall is one of the closest to Cambridge. And one of the issues is they have a lot of through traffic despite not being a main road. But it's another well-kept hall that is the heart of its community. Kairangi Hall is not a council hall at all, but it's part of a settlement that began in the area many years ago.  and it serves a community that is very much a part of Waipa. The Kairangi people are concerned about the number of recreational cyclists that regularly pass through their district, but have no access to public toilets. So they tend to use one at the hall. So an interesting discussion was had as to how this could be remedied, because some of these cyclists are actually just using the roadside, not a good look. One suggestion was that a welcome to a Kairangi site  be placed on the roadside, welcome the cyclists and others, reminding them that the road was not the toilet or similar wording. I've also thought it would actually be quite good to have signs at quite close to local halls, just to welcome people to those particular districts like Horohoro, Mangatatari, Fencore, just so people know that there are little communities here.  At this hall at Kairangi, which has been maintained very well by the community, it was suggested that they could apply to the community board for funding for a project under our discretionary grants scheme. There are a small number of residents in this area that care for the hall, but it seems that not many of the area's residents are involved. They tend to look through to Cambridge, I suspect, but it would be good to see some revitalization there.
